content: The "Student Disciplinary Fairness Act of 2013" aims to address the issue of juveniles entering the criminal justice system for minor school infractions. Research shows that zero-tolerance policies lead to increased incarceration rates for students, resulting in negative long-term outcomes such as lower educational attainment and higher likelihood of recidivism. The "Student Disciplinary Fairness Act of 2013" establishes the Office of School and Discipline Policy within the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention to reduce juvenile incarceration stemming from school-related activities. The Office of School and Discipline Policy will collect data on juvenile students' arrests and work to reduce incarceration for school rule violations. They will collaborate with various organizations to implement alternatives to detention programs and study the impact of school resource officers on arrest rates. The Office of School and Discipline Policy aims to reduce juvenile students' incarceration for school rule violations by implementing alternatives to detention programs and studying the impact of school resource officers on arrest rates. The School Discipline Policy Grant Program (SEC. 603) aims to reduce juvenile incarceration for school rule violations through alternative detention programs and studying the impact of school resource officers on arrest rates. The Director may grant funds to States, local governments, and educational agencies to reduce juvenile arrests for school rule violations. Applicants demonstrating progress towards this goal will receive preference in funding allocation. Students are arrested and incarcerated for school rule violations or other activities determined by the Director to further the purpose described in section 601(b). The text defines key terms related to schools, school resource officers, and local educational agencies. It also defines a juvenile student as a juvenile enrolled in school. Additionally, it authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2014 and 2015 to implement the provisions outlined in the text. SEC. 4. CONDITIONS FOR STATES TO RECEIVE ``COPS ON THE BEAT'' GRANTS. Section 1702(c) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include new requirements for State or local government applicants regarding the administration of juvenile justice in accordance with the United States Constitution and specific constitutional amendments. Juveniles arrested must have probable cause specific to them and receive procedural due process, including notice, legal representation, and protections against self-incrimination. Juveniles arrested must have procedural due process, including legal representation, protections against self-incrimination, and an opportunity to cross-examine witnesses. Probation contracts for juveniles should not include clauses they cannot understand or that could lead to incarceration for school rule violations. The Attorney General is granted authority to access juvenile justice records through subpoenas. Additionally, a Department of Education grant program is established. The Secretary of Education will provide grants for training school personnel in de-escalation techniques to address student behavior and avoid involving law enforcement. Eligible entities must submit an application demonstrating compliance with federal school discipline data reporting requirements. The Secretary of Education will provide grants for training school personnel in de-escalation techniques to address student behavior and avoid involving law enforcement. Eligible entities must comply with federal school discipline data reporting requirements, including providing complete information to Department of Education surveys. Elementary or secondary schools can only receive assistance from one eligible entity during a grant period. Definitions include "eligible entity" as a State, local government unit, or juvenile justice agency. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 defines terms related to school personnel. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2014 and 2015 to carry out this section.
